framework_intro.para:
Here is a framework to help you write an effective health sciences case study. There are spaces for you to add your own text.
Remember that you can double-click on any word to look it up in the dictionary.

step.label: What is a health sciences case study?

commentary.para: Case studies are widely used in the health sciences. The case presentation invariably relates to a real-life patient and typically contains the presenting features and the relevant medical/social/family history, along with investigations, treatment and follow-up.

The primary aim of case studies in the health field generally is the identification and definition of a problem followed by recommendations. However, different areas of the health sciences may have different aims, such as: proposing a plan of action or a care treatment plan, or suggesting interventions. There may also be more reflective practice in some case studies than others.
Here is the framework that was used to present this case study.
The extracts in the model are taken from a case study relating to a patient suffering from Parkinson's Disease, written by a student nurse.
The Introduction is omitted from the model, but it identifies the patient under study and the framework and criteria for assessment.

The Case Presentation is omitted from the model, but it presents the patient's case, explaining that the patient suffers from a long-term condition and is cared for by her husband. It states that the patient was admitted to hospital following a fall in her home. The writer then identifies a problem: failure in the care provided at discharge.

The section first gives background information, which is omitted here. The writer outlines The National Service Framework for Long-term Conditions, supported by statistics and references to official and professional sources.
These points are related to the case, leading to questions about the management of the case.
The legal guidelines are set out.
Then the particulars of the case are assessed, leading to criticism of the shortcomings.
This contains learning points for future care.
The most important point is identified first.

Evaluation words and phrases (negative and positive)
Modal verbs used to make recommendations
Words and phrases to state purpose

checklist.point: When you plan your case study, consider your reasons for choosing a particular case, the criteria for analysing it, how realistic and achievable your recommendations are, and what can be learnt from the study.
Make notes for your case study and keep a record of the sources you want to use to support your points.
Organize your notes into the framework.
Consider the audience for your case study.
Draft your case study, focusing on ensuring that your ideas are clear and your arguments are logically structured.
Review and revise your draft as necessary.
Use academic language.
Language bank: describing the case
Language bank: evaluating the case
Language bank: making recommendations
Language bank: stating why recommendations are made (purpose)
Remember to use sources to support your points.
Think about the writing process.
Have I introduced the case, identifying a problem or describing an issue?
Have I presented the case from a medical, social and family perspective?
Have I evaluated the case and made the criteria clear?
Have I made recommendations to address the problems I identified?
Have I made general reflections on what can be learned from this case?
Have I used appropriate language to describe, evaluate and make recommendations?
Have I quoted and referenced my sources accurately?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?

paragraph.name: Evaluation of the case
paragraph.desc: Evaluate the case using criteria such as legislation and/or professional guidelines.

content.para:
As seen in the above case study, Mr Jones suggested he was unable to manage the sole care of his wife. Many authors have suggested anxiety and depression to be high amongst full-time carers (Playfer et al., 2001; Twigg et al., 1994). So, what acts, policies, recommendations and frameworks have been set in place to ensure that Mr Jones is able not only to provide a good quality of life to his wife, but to expect a quality of life he was unable to have without outside input? Furthermore, was the discharge planning in hospital of clinical governance standard, or did the multi-disciplinary team overlook Mr Jones's needs?
• Supporting the carer through clinical governance and policies
Ensuring patients and carers receive the gold standard of care is the responsibility of clinical governance. Implemented in the 1998 Health Act …, it set out to provide a quality service and clear lines for accountability, the management of risks and addressing poor performance (National Audit Office, 2007) … [Further paragraphs (omitted here) discuss the legal guidelines and clinical best practice in more detail.] …
Applying the National Service Framework for Long-term Conditions (2005) to the case study leads to the conclusion that health care professionals did not comply with the necessary requirements of the framework. The key requirements of this framework state that the care provided must be patient- and carer-centred so that they can make their own informed decisions on the care that will be installed.
When these guidelines are applied to Mrs Jones and compared with the actions taken by the MDT, those actions appear inadequate. ...
Due to the failure to recognize other falls prevention plans, clinical governance has not been applied at an optimal level.

paragraph.name: Recommendations
paragraph.desc: Make recommendations addressing any failures or problems you identified.

content.para:
Recommendations
If the planning of Mrs Jones's discharge were to occur again, then the following steps should be taken so that it was carried out in accordance with the Local Discharge Policy (2007) as well as the NICE falls assessment (2004), the Community Care Act (1990), the NSF for Long-term Conditions (2005) and the New Deal for Carers (2008) policy.
First and foremost, admission through to discharge must be personalized to the individual patient (NSF, 2005). This ensures that the patient receives the best standard of care tailored to their needs, in accordance with clinical governance (McSherry, 2007). To ensure this personalized care is put into action, individual care plans must be drawn up so that they include, in Mrs Jones's case, mobility, dignity, falls and hygiene (NSF, 2005; NICE, 2004; Lee, 2008). [Two further paragraphs (omitted here) identify more learning points.]

paragraph.name: Conclusion
paragraph.desc: Summarize the achievements of your assignment and generalize your findings.
paragraph.tip: TIP This may come before the Recommendations section.

content.para:
Conclusion
This assignment has revealed a gap in providing support for informal carers ... Patients with long term conditions, and their carers,are not being provided with the appropriate knowledge needed to live independently, because of poor communication with members of the MDT. As well as this, an increase in funding and therefore availability of services needs to be addressed so that those who need the services can access them easily. To conclude, patients and their carers are the best people to inform health care professionals of their needs, not the other way around.
